title-group.article-title: Palatal Complexity Revisited: An Electropalatographic Analysis of /ɲ/ in Brazilian Portuguese with Comparison to Peninsular Spanish

contrib-group.aff: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ryan Shosted, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Department of Linguistics, 4080 Foreign Languages Building, 707 S. Mathews Avenue, MC-168, Urbana, Illinois 61801, USA Email: rshosted@illinois.edu

abstract.p: Are palatal consonants articulated by multiple tongue gestures (coronal and dorsal) or by a single gesture that brings the tongue into contact with the palate at several places of articulation? The lenition of palatal consonants (resulting in approximants) has been presented as evidence that palatals are simple, not complex: When reduced, they do not lose their coronal gesture and become dorsals; instead, they manifest reduced linguopalatal contact while retaining their anterior place of articulation. The frequently-reported deocclusivization of the Brazilian Portuguese (BP) palatal nasal may support this claim. However, the linguopalatal configuration of this sound has not been studied directly. Electropalatographic evidence from three speakers of BP (compared with data from three speakers of Peninsular Spanish) demonstrates that the palatal nasal is frequently realized as an approximant. There is no evidence of anterior occlusion in BP’s post-palatal, lenited nasal. Under conditions of focus/hyperarticulation, there is no evidence of stronger/more anterior occlusion. We argue that the articulatory target of the BP palatal nasal is neither occluded nor anterior.

sec.title: 1.1 The palatal nasal(s) of Portuguese and Spanish
sec.p: There is no consensus as to whether the consonant represented by <nh> in Portuguese orthography is a palatal nasal stop (Azevedo, 1981; Cruz-Ferreira, 1997) or a patalal nasal approximant (Perini, 2002, p. 13). Allophonic and/or sociolinguistic distribution of these variants, if any, is largely undetermined. In much of the literature on the phonetics of Brazilian Portuguese (BP), there seems to be an assumption that <nh> is a stop that has undergone deocclusivization under certain unspecified conditions and/or by certain groups of speakers. For example, Barbosa and Albano (2004) regard <nh> as a palatal nasal stop, but note that it is frequently realized as a nasalized approximant. Variable deocclusivization of /ɲ/ in Portuguese has been reported by Lipski (1975, p. 75) and Parkinson (1979, p. 44). Hajek (1997, p. 174) finds reports of deoccluded palatal nasals consistent with acoustic measurements by Martins (1975), who shows that the palatal nasal is the shortest nasal consonant in Portuguese.1

There is a fairly extensive dialectological literature on the palatal nasal in Brazil, though little, if any, instrumental data have been collected on the topic. For example, based on phonetic transcriptions of 3,154 phonemic palatal nasals gathered during interviews with 24 informants in Belo Horizonte (a city in the southeastern state of Minas Gerais), Pinheiro (2009) claims that only around 21% of the palatal nasals are occluded.2 Soares (2002) also finds unoccluded palatal nasals to be prevalent in Marabá, in the northern state of Pará. Aguiar (1937) notes that the unoccluded variant is typical of the northeastern state of Ceará and Aragão (1996) claims that, in Fortaleza (a city in Ceará) unoccluded /ɲ/ is more common before the close vowel /i/ than before the relatively open vowels /a ϵ ɔ/. Finally, Almeida (2004) observes unoccluded productions of /ɲ/ in Vale do Cuiabá, Mato Grosso, a state in the central-west region of Brazil.

Instrumental evidence of the unoccluded character of Portuguese /ɲ/ has been presented only recently. Based on aerodynamic and acoustic data, Shosted and Hualde (2010) conclude that BP <nh> is less occluded than both /n/ in the sequence /nj/ and the palatal nasal /ɲ/ of Puerto Rican Spanish. While acoustic and aerodynamic data provide indirect evidence of the unoccluded nature of this segment, a direct demonstration requires articulatory evidence, which is absent from the literature. The exact place of articulation of Portuguese /ɲ/ is also undetermined. In this paper we employ electropalatography (EPG) to elucidate the manner and place of articulation of BP’s palatal nasal, and to identify its relationship with related sounds in BP and a related language, Peninsular Spanish (PS).

The palatal nasal /ɲ/ in PS is typified by a great deal of contact in both the front and back regions of the palate, suggesting ‘alveopalatal’ is a more appropriate label (Fernández Planas, 2000, pp. 200–208). Because there is a lack of articulatory evidence regarding BP /ɲ/, it is uncertain whether the sound shares place and manner characteristics with the alveopalatal /ɲ/ of PS. Even though PS /ɲ/ is well-documented in the articulatory literature (Fernández Planas, 2000), we will collect a set of comparable data for PS and BP in order to build our own statistical models that compare characteristics of the two sounds directly.

Diachronic evidence sheds little light on whether BP /ɲ/ should be regarded as a conditionally deoccluded stop or a phonemic approximant. While it is clear that both a palatal nasal approximant and a palatal nasal stop existed in Galician-Portuguese of the fourteenth century (Williams, 1962) and later merged, it is not clear whether the result of this merger was an approximant or a stop, or if the merger was ever completed. Comparison with European Portuguese (EP) is inconclusive: while some evidence suggests speakers produce the palatal nasal stop only (de Oliveira, 2009, p. 132), palatographic confirmation is still necessary.3 Even if EP /ɲ/ is shown to be a stop, this development may be considered an innovation that occurred after the settlement of Brazil. In fact, Shosted and Hualde (2010) propose that BP’s unoccluded /ɲ/ may be a conservative trait of medieval Galician-Portuguese.

Deocclusivization of /ɲ/ has been reported in several Romance languages besides BP, including Spanish (Lipski, 1989) and French (Simon, 1970). To our knowledge, however, the linguopalatal configuration of deoccluded palatal nasals has not been studied in depth. Quilis (1993, p. 203) reports that the palatal nasal of Cuban Spanish may be realized as a nasal glide. Straka (1979, p. 345) presents a few palatograms of deoccluded palatal nasals in French and Provençal. These variants of [͂] have a great deal of lateral-anterior contact; some of the palatograms manifest a fairly narrow gap at the alveolar ridge. We know of no systematic EPG work on palatal lenition, the process which presumably accounts for this development in languages like French.

sec.title: 1.2 Are palatals complex?
sec.p: Recasens, Fontdevila, and Pallarès (1995) use the realization of deoccluded palatal consonants to argue against the hypothesis that palatal consonants are by nature complex, that is, involve multiple lingual gestures (Keating, 1988; Keating & Lahiri, 1993; Lahiri & Evers, 1991). Recasens et al. (1995, p. 274) claim that the deocclusivization of /ɲ/ does not result “from the loss of an apicoalveolar or a dorsopalatal gesture… but from articulatory changes affecting a simple alveopalatal gesture.” According to this hypothesis, lenition is manifested by a central gap in an otherwise canonical palatal contact pattern. A similar proposal has been made by Straka (1979, pp. 327, 345). Besides Straka’s palatograms, however, we know of no published data that exemplify the palatographic characteristics of lenited palatals.

The reason for this lacuna may be technological. The place and manner (stop vs. approximant) of nasal consonants are difficult to verify using acoustic information alone. Place cues, which are relatively easy to detect in oral consonants, become more difficult to detect with the addition of nasal and paranasal resonances. The vibration of air in the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses increases spectral bandwidths and introduces additional poles and zeros into the transfer function. The effect is to smear bands of spectral energy in such a way that place of articulation becomes more challenging to recover. While the acoustic consequences of increased velopharyngeal aperture on place of articulation can be modeled computationally (Pruthi, Espy-Wilson, & Story, 2007; Rong & Kuehn, 2010; Stevens, 1998), the relatively inaccessible nasal geometry of individual subjects has important acoustic consequences which require independent measurement (Engwall, Delvaux, & Metens, 2006). One result of these complications is that observations of formant structure do not guarantee predictions of place in nasal consonants or oral configuration in vowels (Carignan, Shosted, Shih, & Rong, 2011).4 The relative paucity of direct articulatory information about nasal consonants, even in well-studied languages, necessarily limits our ability to understand the synchronic and diachronic phonology of nasals (Rubach, 2008).

sec.title: 1.3 Purpose of the study
sec.p: In this paper we present EPG data for two closely related language varieties, BP and Peninsular Spanish (PS). We will make reference to the articulatory processes at work in the realization of the unoccluded palatal nasal (reported for BP) and compare these with the processes at work in the realization of the occluded palatal nasal (reported for PS; e.g., Fernández Planas, 2000, among others). For comparative purposes, we gathered data on the realization of /nj/ and /j/ in both languages. In BP and PS, the components of the sequence /nj/ are considered to be part of the same syllable. The sequence /nj/ can be compared with the palatal nasal in both languages to understand the potential role of intergestural timing in the production of both consonants (Recasens, 1984; Recasens & Romero, 1997). The oral approximant /j/ was recorded in both languages in order to compare it with the deoccluded palatal nasal in BP,5 which has been transcribed as a nasalized palatal approximant [j͂]. We present standard temporal and contact measures to better understand the production of alveolo-palatal nasals, palatal glides, and sequences of alveolar stop and palatal glide in these languages.

We find that BP and PS /ɲ/ present quite different patterns of linguopalatal constriction, to the point that it may be misleading to use the same phonetic symbol for both. A majority of BP palatal nasals are realized without complete contact, that is, as a nasal palatal approximant [j͂] (whose pattern of constriction is, nevertheless, not identical to that of oral [j]). Full contact in the palatal nasal is favored by the presence of a preceding /i/. When occlusion does occur in BP tokens, it is post-palatal, providing circumstantial evidence that the coronal articulation manifested in the PS palatal nasal has been lost in the BP variety of our subjects. We find it unlikely that the more canonical palatal nasal of PS is somehow the ‘target’ for BP productions, since we find relatively little evidence of an anterior, occluded pattern ever occurring in the realization of BP /ɲ/.

sec.title: 2.1 Speakers
sec.p: The Brazilian Portuguese-speaking subjects were three females raised, respectively, in the cities of Rio de Janeiro (BP1), São Paulo (BP2), and Salvador, Bahia (BP3). Little is known about varying pronunciation of the palatal nasal in these cities/regions of Brazil. To the extent that the dialects of São Paulo and/or Rio de Janeiro are similar to that of Belo Horizonte with regard to the palatal nasal, the results presented by Pinheiro (2009) may be useful for considering the speech of BP1 and BP2; similarly, the findings of Aguiar (1937), Aragão (1996), and Soares (2002) may be relevant to the speech of BP3. As noted in the introduction, the palatal nasal in Belo Horizonte is occluded in only 21% of cases. An anonymous reviwer has pointed out that northern varieties of Brazilian Portuguese may present more evidence of occlusion, so this may be the case for BP3.

The Spanish-speaking subjects were three males from Spain. One speaker was from Murcia, in southeastern Spain (PS1); the other two speakers were from the North-Central Castilian region (PS2 and PS3). PS2 is the second author. We know of no reports describing variation in the palatal nasal produced in these regions of Spain.

sec.title: 2.2.1 Experiment I: Standard laboratory speech
sec.p: For the first experiment, the recorded materials were identical to those in Shosted and Hualde (2010). Using reverse Spanish and Portuguese dictionaries (Bosque & Pérez Fernández, 1987; d’Andrade Pardal, 1993) balanced sets of five (5) word-final -/aCa/, -/oCa/, and -/eCa/ tokens were constructed where C included the palatal nasal, /nj/, and /j/. Additional sets of five (5) -/iɲa/ and -/uɲa/ forms were collected. In total, 55 lexical items were chosen for both languages (Table 1).

caption.p: Materials for the first experiment with examples from Portuguese (first line, each cell) and Spanish (second line)

fn.p: Cells marked with ‘*’ were not represented in the materials. See Shosted and Hualde (2010) for a complete list.

sec.p: Whenever possible, Portuguese and Spanish cognates were collected in order to reduce the degrees of freedom in the materials. Lexical stress was placed only on the syllable immediately preceding the target segment; this stress pattern is the most frequent in both BP and PS.

sec.title: 2.2.2 Experiment II: Hyperarticulated speech
sec.p: A second experiment, which we will call the ‘hyperspeech’ experiment or Experiment II, included materials designed to explore how speakers of BP might hyperarticulate the palatal nasal consonant. The speaker produced forced-contrast or ‘dictation’ phrases (Port & Crawford, 1989) like Disse bonha não bônia6 ‘I said bonha not bônia’. The (underlined) test items consisted of /C1VC2a/ words (mostly nonsense forms) where V included /a e o/, C2 included /ɲ nj j/ and C1 included /p t k b d g/ for variety. The materials were designed so that in both first and second positions words with /ɲ/ appeared in contrast to words with /nj/ and /j/; contrasting words differed only in C2. The speaker was instructed to emphasize the first word in the pair; appropriate intonation was modeled by the researcher who uttered a non-test phrase as an example. Using de Jong and Zawaydeh’s (2002, p. 54) most basic formulation of phonological focus as stress that is not restricted to the syllable, the word appearing in first position may be considered ‘focused’ and the word appearing in second position may be considered ‘unfocused’.

sec.title: 2.3 Procedures
sec.p: Acoustic data and linguopalatal contact were sampled using the Articulate Instruments WinEPG system (Articulate Instruments Ltd., 2008; Hardcastle, 1972). Speakers were recorded in a quiet room in the Phonetics and Phonology Laboratory at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Acoustic data were sampled at 22.05 kHz; EPG data were sampled at 100 Hz. In Experiment I, speakers uttered test items in the carrier phrase, Digo ___ para ti ‘I say ___ to you’. The phrase is phonetically similar when produced in Spanish and Portuguese, with minor differences in pronunciation of no relevance to the present research questions. In both experiments, test items were presented in randomized order in three complete blocks, resulting in three repetitions of each test item. There were no recording errors in Experiment I. In Experiment II, however, two tokens were lost due to recording error: one repetition of a /ɲ/ × /j/ phrase and one repetition of a /j/ × /ɲ/ phrase (resulting in [(6 × 3) – 1] = 17 tokens of these pairs); other pairs like /nj/ × /j/ were represented by 6 × 3 = 18 repetitions. All speakers participated in Experiment I; only BP3 participated in Experiment II.

sec.title: 2.4 Instrumentation
sec.p: Each speaker wore a 62-sensor Reading-style artificial palate (Hardcastle, 1972) based on a custom dental model cast by an orthodontist. Acoustics were recorded using an AKG C-520 head-mounted microphone positioned approximately 5 cm from the corner of the mouth.

sec.title: 2.5 Data post-processing
sec.p: The binary EPG data recorded with Articulate Assistant (Articulate Instruments Ltd., 2008) were converted to text files using code adapted from loadepg.m (Nguyen, 1997). A Matlab structure combined the synchronized audio and EPG data. A custom-written graphical user interface (EPG-GUI) in Matlab 2009b allowed for visualization and annotation of the audio and EPG signals in tandem (Shosted, 2011a).

sec.title: 2.6 Data annotation
sec.p: Our primary goal was to automatically detect and describe consonantal event(s) in the test (VCV) material using objective, replicable criteria. As a first pass, the third author used EPG-GUI to delineate boundaries (in seconds) on the acoustic waveform. The first boundary marked the beginning of the vowel preceding the consonant in question. The second boundary marked the end of the vowel following the consonant in question. For example, in the Portuguese word sanha ‘wrath’, the final VCV sequence was bounded. In selecting these initial boundaries an overcautious approach was unnecessary for a number of reasons. First, only the consonant was of direct interest to us. Specifically, degree of constriction in the consonant was our primary focus. Second, the final vowel was always /a/ and therefore reasonably considered less constricted than the segments /ɲ nj j/.

We observed that articulatory traces of the consonant preceding the relevant VCV material could persist well into the vowel, potentially interfering with automatic detection of the consonant of interest to us. Therefore, the left-most, manually annotated boundary was adjusted automatically based on the Contact Centrality Index (CC; Fontdevila, Pallarès, & Recasens, 1994, p. 145). CC represents the degree of sagitto-medial contact along the palate, with increasing weights assigned to symmetrical columns of electropalate sensors that lie closer to the midline. The formula is given in Equation 1:

where C1 is the sum of activated sensors in the left- and right-most columns, C2 is the sum of activated sensors in second-to-the-left- and second-to-the-right-most columns, and so forth. According to Fontdevila et al. (1994, p. 145), “[CC] values increase primarily as a function of the activation of successively more electrodes on a given row or column and, to a lesser extent, of variations in overall linguopalatal contact pattern.” For example, CC values approaching 1 are associated with complete contact at the two centermost columns of the electropalate, while values between 0.008 and 0.08 are associated with contact exclusively at the lateral edges of the electropalate. Because CC increases as central occlusion increases it can be used as a measure of (central) consonantal constriction; moreover, CC maxima can be interpreted as the most consonantal, that is, most constricted, moments in a signal.

Figure 1 shows the annotation schema, including manually and automatically selected boundaries. First, vowel boundaries in the VCV sequence were manually segmented and rounded to the nearest EPG sample (dark vertical bars at 620 ms and 920 ms). From left to right, the first CC minimum (or range of equal minima) within these bounds was automatically detected. The first CC minimum (or last point in the first range of equal minima) occurring after the left-most annotated boundary was automatically selected as the new left-most boundary (dark dashed vertical bar at 680 ms). Functionally, this boundary meant the end of coarticulation originating from the consonant preceding the test (VCV) material. As seen in Figure 1, this event could occur well after the onset of the vowel. Between this new boundary and the original right-most boundary (manually annotated), the maximum CC value was calculated. In Figure 1, the CC maximum occurs at 780 ms.

caption.p: Annotated /oja/ in Troya, ‘Troy’ uttered by PS3. Sound pressure is plotted in the upper frame and a spectrogram in the middle frame; EPG signals (CC and CAp) are plotted in the lower frame. CC is indicated by the dashed line with shaded squares; CAp is indicated by the solid line with unfilled diamonds. Dark vertical bars (at 620 and 920 ms) indicate manual annotation boundaries. The dashed vertical line falls at the moment before CC begins to rise. The maximum CC value (at 780 ms) is indicated by the light vertical dashed line

sec.title: 2.7 Measures
sec.p: Three EPG indices were calculated at the point of maximum CC: contact anteriority in the ‘palatal zone’ (CAp); contact centrality in the palatal zone (CCp); and contact posteriority (CP).

sec.title: 2.7.1 Contact anteriority in the palatal zone (CAp)
sec.p: CAp is a measure of the anterior placement of the tongue against the hard palate, considering only the four most posterior rows of the palate. This measure has proven effective in differentiating alveolar from palatal nasals in Spanish (Fernández Planas, 2000) and Catalan (Recasens, Farnetani, Fontdevila, & Pallarès, 1993). It is calculated by summing the contact in each horizontal row of sensors (limited to the most posterior four rows) and applying weights so that anterior contact results in a higher CAp value (Fontdevila et al., 1994, p. 145). The formula is given in Equation 2:

where R8 is the sum of activated sensors in the most posterior row, R7 is the sum of activated sensors in the second-to-the-most-posterior row, and so forth. Using this procedure, our measure of place of articulation is limited to that portion of the signal characterized by greatest central constriction (including occlusion) at the back of the artificial palate.

sec.title: 2.7.2 Contact centrality in the palatal zone (CCp)
sec.p: The formula for calculation of CCp is identical to the formula for CC given in Equation 1 (Section 2.6) except that the columnar inputs (C 1, C 2, etc.) are summed using only data from the fifth to eighth rows of the artificial palate. CCp is a useful measure, particularly for differentiating occluded from unoccluded BP palatal nasals, where we will show there is little if any contact in the anterior region of the palate.

sec.title: 2.7.3 Contact posteriority (CP)
sec.p: CP is calculated by applying increasing weights to increasingly posterior rows of sensors on the artificial palate using Equation 3 (Fontdevila et al., 1994, p. 145):
The resulting CP value is higher for configurations typified by more contact at the back of the artificial palate.

sec.title: 2.7.4 Complete occlusion
sec.p: In some tokens it was possible to observe the presence of complete occlusion across the breadth of the artificial palate. In most instances of occlusion, at least one row of sensors is entirely ‘on’, so simply summing the number of contacts across each row is sufficient for detecting occlusion (Cho & Keating, 2009; Gibbon, Yuen, Lee, & Adams, 2007). However, in our data we observed occlusions typified by incomplete occlusion on one row, with complementary (and sometimes trivially redundant) occlusion on an adjacent row. In order to account for this kind of occlusion, pairs of adjacent sensor rows on the artificial palate are summed in column-wise fashion. If two sensors in the same 2 × 1 column are ‘on’, then the result is 2; if only one of these sensors is ‘on’, the result is 1; if neither sensor is ‘on’, the result is 0. This summed array is then divided by itself so that 2’s are normalized to 1’s and 0’s become undefined (NaN, i.e., not-a-number). The resulting array, including now only 1’s and NaN’s, is summed again. If the result is equal to the number of sensors in a row (6 in the case of the first/anterior-most pair of rows, 8 in all other cases),7 then the result is interpreted as a complete occlusion across the palate. Like other EPG indices, this occlusion signal may be regarded as time-varying, though unlike other indices, it is binary (1 = complete occlusion; 0 = no occlusion).8 Figure 2 shows an annotated token with overlaid CC and CAp signals plus the binary occlusion signal. We measured presence of complete occlusion as well as duration of complete occlusion in the test material.

caption.p: Annotated /iɲa/ in linha, ‘line’, uttered by BP2. This token demonstrates complete occlusion (atypical of BP /ɲ/). Conventions are as in Figure 1 but complete occlusion is also represented, using the dash-dot line and grey shaded circle

sec.title: 2.7.5 Consonant duration
sec.p: Consonant duration was taken to be the duration of complete occlusion, if occlusion was present as defined in Section 2.7.4 (Recasens & Espinosa, 2006). When complete occlusion was absent, a different metric was used. We considered the duration of the consonant to be the portion of the signal where the CC was greater than or equal to 80% of the maximum CC, both to the left and to the right of the maximum (Figure 3). The 80% threshold was chosen after inspecting a number of /VɲV/ and /VjV/ sound pressure signals and looking for reasonable estimates based on the attenuation in the waveform amplitude (cf. Scobbie & Pouplier, 2010). A larger threshold would of course result in shorter durations and a smaller threshold would result in longer durations. We acknowledge that our measure may overestimate or underestimate the length of consonants without complete occlusion but we consider the replicability of the measure, and its uniformity across tokens, advantageous.

caption.p: Annotated /eɲa/ in lenha, ‘log’, uttered by BP1 with conventions as in Figure 1. The solid line with shaded square is the CC; the maximum value occurs at 1320 ms. Thresholding was set to 80% of the maximum CC value (horizontal dashed line); the distance between the two vertical dash-dot lines is regarded as the duration of the consonant

sec.title: 2.8 Statistical methods
sec.p: Statistical analyses were performed using R 2.13.0 (R Development Core Team, 2011). Linear mixed effects models were designed using the lme function in the nlme package (Baayen, 2008; Littell, Pendergast, & Natarajan, 2000; Pinheiro & Bates, 2000). In Experiment I, separate models were implemented for the two languages. Consonant was designated as a fixed effect and Speaker was designated as a random effect with Repetition as a nested random effect. Because repeated measures were used, it was sometimes necessary to correct for significant changes in variance across repetitions (Gueorguieva & Krystal, 2004). This was done by applying an autoregressive covariance structure to any mixed effects models that showed evidence of significant autocorrelations (Littell et al., 2000). Significant autocorrelations were assesssed (at α = 0.01) by calculating the empirical autocorrelation function for the within-group residuals from the linear mixed effects fit (Pinheiro & Bates, 2000).

Tukey’s test for honestly significant differences (Miller, 1981; Yandell, 1997) was used to determine which differences among the three consonants were significant. Tests for cross-linguistic differences in the production of /ɲ/ used Language as a fixed effect and Speaker as a random effect, with Repetition as a nested random effect. Chi-square tests for each language were implemented with counts of occlusion versus non-occlusion as dependent variables; Consonant was the independent variable. For chi-square tests comparing /ɲ/ and /nj/, only the vowel contexts /a/, /e/, and /o/ were used; this was to avoid imbalance in the number of observed palatal nasals (see below).

The same statistical methods were used for Experiment II, in which only speaker BP3 participated. The analysis was carried out only for the palatal nasal. For the linear mixed effect model, Prosodic Position (focused/unfocused) was a fixed effect and Repetition was a random effect.

Because it was not possible to find sufficient /ija/, /inja/, /uja/, and /unja/ tokens to complete balanced sets in Experiment I (Portuguese, for example, has no /ija/ tokens in its lexicon), only /aC(j)a/, /eC(j)a/, and /oC(j)a/ tokens were submitted to the within-language linear mixed effects models. The inclusion of high vowel tokens, which were available exclusively for the palatal nasal, would likely increase the variance for /Vɲa/ tokens and thereby add noise to any model focusing on within-language differences between consonants. Even if the effect of vowel was included in such a model, there would be much more data for /ɲ/ than the other consonants. Nevertheless, because we are the first to present EPG data for the BP palatal nasal, we include descriptive data and palatograms for the high vowel tokens to illustrate the production of /ɲ/ in as many vocalic environments as possible. In addition, high vowel tokens were included in statistical tests investigating the differences between BP and PS palatal nasals, where the sets were balanced.

sec.title: 3.1 Palatograms
sec.p: Following Recasens and Espinosa (2006), Figures 4 (BP) and 5 (PS) include average, probabilistic linguopalatal configurations (palatograms) for each VC combination produced by each speaker. Each cell in Figures 4 and 5 represents the palatogram at the moment of maximum constriction / occlusion averaged across 15 tokens (five words × three repetitions; see Section 2.2).

caption.p: Brazilian Portuguese palatograms at moment of maximum constriction averaged across repetitions. Black shading indicates linguopalatal contact in > 80% of repeated tokens; 75% grey = contact in 60–80%; 50% grey = contact in 40–60%; 25% grey = contact in 20–40%; white = contact in < 20% of tokens
Peninsular Spanish palatograms at moment of maximum constriction averaged across repetitions. Shading conventions as in Figure 4

sec.p: The top row of boxes in each palatogram represents the most anterior row of sensors on the artificial palate. Black shading means that in over 80% of the tokens the relevant sensor was contacted at the moment of maximum constriction; 75% grey = 60–80%; 50% grey = 40–60%; 25% grey = 20–40%; unfilled = less than 20%. Since the palates used for this visualization always came from the most constricted part of the consonantal articulation, the /nj/ tokens necessarily reflect the moment of maximum constriction during the completely occluded (thus maximally constricted) alveolar nasal, not the palatal (less constricted) approximant. (Of course, as an anonymous reviewer points out, /n/ is undoubtedly coarticulated with the following /j/ in this sequence.)

We note briefly that the palatal nasal of BP seems to manifest complete occlusion only rarely. Moreover, we note that for many of the /ɲ/ tokens there is little contact in the anterior rows of the palate. This is in contrast to the alveolo-palatal nasal of PS which manifests extensive anterior contact (Kochetov & Colantoni, 2011). Finally, we draw attention to the similarities between BP /ɲ/ and /j/, which both have limited anterior contact, though /ɲ/ appears to be more anterior.9

sec.title: 3.2 Results of linear mixed effects models
sec.p: Table A.1 (Appendix A) reports the means and standard deviations of the measures described in Section 2.7. A summary, including only vowels /a e o/, appears in Table 2.

caption.p: Means and standard deviations of measures described in Section 2.7 (for the vowels /a e o/ only)

fn.p: For breakdown by speaker and vowel, see Table A.1 (Appendix A).

sec.title: 3.2.1 Contact anteriority in the ‘palatal zone’ (CAp)
sec.p: For BP, CAp at the moment of maximum constriction was associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 135.64, p < 0.0001 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed that differences between the consonant pair /ɲ/–/j/ were not significant, p > 0.05, but differences between /nj/–/j/ were significant, p < 0.0001; differences between the consonant pair /nj/–/ɲ/ were also significant, p < 0.0001. Regarding sensor activation in the ‘palatal zone’ only, /ɲ/ was more anterior (M = 0.82, SD = 0.06) than /j/ (M = 0.67, SD = 0.16) but more posterior than /nj/ (M = 0.86, SD = 0.05).

For PS, CAp at the moment of maximum constriction was associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 219.37, p < 0.0001 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed significant differences between the consonant pairs /ɲ/–/nj/, /nj/–/j/, p < 0.0001, and /ɲ/–/nj/, p < 0.05. As measured by CAp, the places of articulation for PS /ɲ/ (M = 0.97, SD = 0.03) and /nj/ (M = 0.81, SD = 0.1) are different at the point of maximum constriction.

CAp of /ɲ/ is associated with language, F(1, 4) = 53.8, p < 0.01 (significant autocorrelations in the model were corrected by applying an autoregressive covariance structure). The average CAp for BP /ɲ/ is 0.38 (SD = 0.06) while the average CAp for PS /ɲ/ is 0.77 (SD = 0.05), indicating that within the ‘palatal zone’ BP /ɲ/ is more posterior than its PS counterpart.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Contact centrality in the ‘palatal zone’ (CCp)
sec.p: For BP, maximum CCp (contact centrality in the palatal zone) was associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 94.27, p < 0.0001 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed that differences between the consonant pairs /ɲ/ and /j/ were significant, p < 0.01, but differences between the other pairs were not. BP /j/ (M = 0.36, SD = 0.14) and /nj/ (M = 0.42, SD = 0.15) manifest similar constrictions in the palatal zone while /ɲ/ (M = 0.55, SD = 0.14) is significantly more constricted than /j/, though similar to /nj/.

For PS, maximum CCp was associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 348.01, p < 0.0001 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed that differences between all pairs were significant: /nj/ vs. /ɲ/, p < 0.0001; /nj/ vs. /j/, p < 0.001; and /ɲ/ vs. /j/, p < 0.01. /ɲ/ manifested the highest degree of contact centrality in the palatal zone (M = 0.72, SD = 0.15), followed by /j/ (M = 0.51, SD = 0.16). The smallest CCp value was manifested by /nj/ (M = 0.26, SD = 0.15). CCp of /ɲ/ was not associated with language, F(1, 4) = 3.03, p > 0.05.

Plots of CAp and CCp for the test consonants in various vowel contexts are given in Figures 6 (PS) and 7 (BP). For each consonant, each mark indicates the mean values (across tokens and repetitions) for one speaker. Figure 6 shows how CCp and CAp alone clearly differentiate PS /nj/ from both /ɲ/ and /j/. Figure 7 shows that, at least for the non-front vowel contexts, BP /ɲ/ and /nj/ are clearly differentiated in terms of CCp and CAp. Likewise, the BP consonants /j/ and /ɲ/ appear differentiable in the vowel contexts /a/ and /o/ but not /e/.

caption.p: CAp and CCp values taken at the maximum constriction during the consonants of interest. Each mark shows the average value across words and repetitions produced by one speaker of PS (total number of speakers = 3; <nh> = /ɲ/)

CAp and CCp values taken at the maximum constriction during the consonants of interest. Each mark shows the average value across words and repetitions produced by one speaker of BP (total number of speakers = 3; <nh> = /ɲ/)

sec.title: 3.2.3 Contact posteriority (CP)
sec.p: For BP, CP at the moment of maximum constriction was associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 127.20, p < 0.0001 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed that differences between the consonant pairs /ɲ/–/j/ and /ɲ/–/nj/ were significant, p < 0.01, p < 0.01. The difference in CP between the consonant pair /nj/–/j/ was not significant. This suggests that BP /ɲ/ (M = 0.87, SD = 0.01) and /j/ (M = 0.85, SD = 0.01) have different posterior contact patterns; more posterior contact is associated with /ɲ/. Combining this result with CAp (see Section 3.2.1), BP /ɲ/ manifests both more posterior contact and more anterior contact (in the palatal zone) than BP /j/. CP of /ɲ/ was not associated with language, F(1, 4) = 1.52, p > 0.05.

sec.title: 3.2.4 Consonantal duration
sec.p: For BP, consonantal duration is associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 5.07, p < 0.01 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed that only /j/ (M = 47.26 ms, SD = 26.83) and /ɲ/ (M = 38.81 ms, SD = 23.44) were significantly different from one another.

For PS, length is associated with consonant, F(2, 394) = 182.29, p < 0.0001 (no significant autocorrelations were observed). Tukey’s test revealed that differences between the consonant pairs /ɲ/–/j/, p < 0.0001, and /nj/–/j/, p < 0.0001, were significant, but not between the pair /ɲ/–/nj/, p > 0.50. This suggests that /ɲ/ (M = 54.44 ms, SD = 21.08) and /nj/ (M = 58.81 ms, SD = 18.2) are similar in duration, but both are substantially longer than /j/ (M = 21.93 ms, SD = 13.35).
BP /ɲ/ was shorter than PS /ɲ/ (15.63 ms on average); this difference was significant, F(1, 4) = 17.35, p < 0.05 (no significant autocorrelations were observed).

sec.title: 3.2.5 Frequency of occlusion
sec.p: Table 3 presents frequency data relating to the presence/absence of a complete linguopalatal occlusion (as defined in Section 2.2) for the three consonants of interest in both languages. Data include all vowel environments. Of particular interest is the fact that 71% of BP alveolo-palatal nasals in the corpus are produced without occlusion. This confirms the report by Pinheiro (2009), who impressionistically determined that approximately 79% of over 3,000 palatal nasals were unoccluded. In our corpus, PS alveolo-palatal nasals fail to manifest occlusion rather infrequently (only 18% are unoccluded). BP /nj/ is produced without occlusion in even fewer instances (10%). Occlusion of /j/ is unattested in our BP corpus, while it is relatively common in PS (Hualde, 2005, p. 165; Martínez Celdrán & Fernández Planas, 2007, p. 63).

caption.p: Presence/absence of complete linguopalatal occlusion across languages (includes all vowels)

sec.p: In Table 4 we report presence/absence of occlusion for BP and PS /ɲ/, according to vowel context. In most vowel contexts, the BP palatal nasal rarely manifests complete occlusion. In the context of preceding high vowels /i/ and /u/, however, there is a relatively high rate of occlusion (66% for high vowels), an effect that is even stronger in the /i/ context (87%). In PS, the reverse is true: the /i/ context has the lowest rate of occlusion. However, this should be considered in light of the fact that, overall, PS /ɲ/ has a much higher rate of occlusion than BP /ɲ/ (82% vs. 29%) and the differences in PS vowel context may not be significant.

caption.p: Presence/absence of complete linguopalatal occlusion among palatal nasals in different preceding vowel contexts

sec.p: While complete occlusion is rare for BP /ɲ/ overall, the tokens showing complete occlusion demonstrate an entirely different linguopalatal configuration from PS /ɲ/ in the same context (Figure 8): in BP the sound is post-palatal, not alveolo-palatal. In Recasens and Espinosa (2006), one Majorcan Catalan speaker also exhibits an occluded post-palatal /ɲ/ similar to that of our BP speakers; however, this place of articulation is attributed to the inclusion of post-palatal /c/ in the phonological inventory of Catalan.

caption.p: Palatograms taken from the first frame showing complete occlusion during the production of (left) BP vinha ‘vineyard’ uttered by BP1 and (right) PS viña ‘vineyard’ uttered by PS3

sec.p: When complete occlusion occurs during a nasal, it can be argued that only the most posterior row relates to the acoustic output of the vocal tract. Anti-resonances are generated in the cavity that lies behind the oral constriction and depend crucially on the length of the oral ‘sidebranch’ that ends at the point of occlusion (Stevens, 1998). For this reason, we highlight the data in Figure 9: virtually all of the occluded BP /ɲ/ tokens are occluded at row 8, while complete occlusion occurs on a wider variety of more anterior rows for speakers of PS.

caption.p: Histogram showing number of /ɲ/ tokens exhibiting complete occlusion by most posterior row of the occlusion. Virtually all tokens with complete occlusion in BP show occlusion in Row 8, the most posterior row on the electropalate, while SP tokens are relatively variable throughout the palatal region [Rows 2–8]

sec.p: We report a larger number of BP /ɲ/ tokens with complete occlusion after /i/ than after other vowels. This may be due to the fact that the tongue is high and complete occlusion is therefore more likely to occur. However, it is also possible that complete occlusion occurs in more BP tokens of /ɲ/ than we can report using EPG, since contact may occur behind the electropalate.

Chi-square tests revealed significantly different rates of occlusion for /nj/ and /ɲ/ in BP, χ2(1, 360) = 123.55, p < 0.0001 and PS, χ2(1, 360) = 23.35, p < 0.001. For both BP and PS, /nj/ was more closely associated with occlusion. Across languages, PS /ɲ/ was more likely to exhibit complete linguopalatal occlusion than BP /ɲ/, χ2(1, 450) = 123.20, p < 0.0001. Finally, vowel context was a significant factor in determining rate of occlusion for BP /ɲ/, χ2(4, 225) = 114.79, p < 0.0001. In BP, the preceding vowel context /i/ was most likely associated with occlusive /ɲ/ (87% of /iɲa/ sequences manifested occlusion), followed by /u/ (44%), then /o/ (9%), /a/ (4%), and finally /e/ (2%).

sec.title: 4 Results of Experiment II
sec.p: Figure 10 presents averaged palatograms for /ɲ/ appearing in first/focused position and second/unfocused position in contrast to /nj/ and /j/ in the ‘hyperspeech’ experiment (Experiment II). Each palatogram represents an average of 17 or 18 repetitions of the sound. For example, the upper right cell represents the articulation of /ɲ/ in phrases like Disse bânia não banha. The unfocused tokens (two right columns of Figure 10) appear to manifest occlusion more frequently than the focused tokens (two left columns of Figure 10). The shading of sensors follows the conventions in Figure 4. The palatograms suggest that, for BP3 (from Salvador, Bahia; the sole participant in Experiment II), focused position may be associated with less linguopalatal contact and fewer instances of complete posterior occlusion.

caption.p: Palatograms for /ɲ/ appearing in first/focused position and second/unfocused position in contrast to /nj/ and /j/ in the ‘hyperspeech’ experiment (Experiment II). Shading conventions as in Figure 4

sec.p: The relationship of CCp and CAp to position/focus (for palatal nasal tokens only) was explored using linear mixed effects models with Repetition as a random factor and Position/Focus as a fixed effect. No significant autocorrelations were observed. Both CCp and CAp were significantly greater in second/unfocused position, F(1, 210) = 36.50, p < 0.0001 and F(1, 210) = 36.50, p < 0.0001, respectively. This suggests that in unfocused position, the palatal nasal was produced with a more central and anterior occlusion (in the palatal zone).

Table 5 shows the occlusion frequency results for Experiment II. The consonant /nj/ never deoccluded and /j/ never occluded, as expected. The ‘hyperspeech’ experiment showed that realizations of /ɲ/ are more variable, though typically unoccluded, as in Experiment I.

caption.p: Frequency results for Experiment II, including occlusions and non-occlusions of consonants in different prosodic positions (first/focused vs. second/unfocused)

fn.p: Tokens are presented in linear order within pairs. For example, /j/ × /ɲ/ means the first/focused token was C-/aja/ and the second/unfocused token was C-/aɲa/. Likewise, Occ0 × Occ1 means Occ0 (no occlusion) occurred in first/focused position and Occ1 (occlusion) occurred in second/unfocused position. Bold denotes cells where occluded manifestations of /ɲ/ are considered.

sec.p: The ‘hyperspeech’ experiment was designed to reveal whether occlusions of BP /ɲ/ were more likely in some prosodic positions. Overall, unfocused /ɲ/ is more likely to occlude than focused /ɲ/: 39.25% (42/107) of the palatal nasals were occluded in second/unfocused position while only 12.15% (13/107) were occluded in first/focused position. This result was significant, χ2(1, 214) = 19.19, p < 0.0001. When in contrast with /j/, /ɲ/ is more than twice as likely to occlude if it occurs in second/unfocused position than if it occurs in first/focused position (occlusions of /ɲ/ in /j/–/ɲ/ pairs occur in 30.2% of the relevant tokens while occlusions of /ɲ/ in /ɲ/–/j/ pairs occur in only 11.3% of the relevant tokens). This result is statistically significant, χ2(1, 106) = 4.65, p < 0.05. Likewise, occlusion of /ɲ/ in contrast with /nj/ is more frequent when /ɲ/ is in second/unfocused position (48.1%) versus when /ɲ/ is in first/focused position (13.0%). This result is also statistically significant, χ2(1, 108) = 14.14, p < 0.001.

Thus, when hyperarticulated (here, in first/focused position) /ɲ/ is more often realized as an approximant; it tends to occlude more frequently when it is in unfocused (second) position. There seems to be no significant increase in occlusion of /ɲ/ when it is contrasted with /nj/ versus /j/, whether in first/focused position, χ2(1, 107) = 0.001, p > 0.05, or second/unfocused position, χ2(1, 107) = 2.90, p > 0.05. Whether contrasted with a nasal stop or an oral approximant, the palatal nasal is most likely to occlude when it is unfocused. This provides evidence that the hyperarticulated target for /ɲ/ is not a forceful occlusion, but an approximant like /j/ where the intended target falls short of the hard palate.

sec.title: 5 Summary of results
sec.p: The results of Experiment I confirm different articulatory realizations of the palatal nasals of PS and BP. The palatal nasal of BP rarely manifests occlusion. In other words, it is most accurately described as a nasalized approximant. This finding is in agreement with previous observations (Aguiar, 1937; Almeida, 2004; Aragão, 1996; Hajek, 1997; Lipski, 1975; Parkinson, 1979; Perini, 2002; Pinheiro, 2009; Soares, 2002) and confirms the instrumental findings of Shosted and Hualde (2010). Given the high frequency with which the BP nasal is realized without occlusion, it seems reasonable to imagine that this articulation is intended, rather than an outcome of hypoarticulation. In fact, if the approximant realization of /ɲ/ is a result of hypoarticulation, one might expect the consonant to manifest occlusion when hyperarticulated, for example, when it occurs under focus. Results of our ‘hyperspeech’ experiment demonstrate the opposite is true: when it occurs under focus, occluded realizations of /ɲ/ are significantly less common. More comprehensive research on focus and its relation to linguopalatal configuration in BP is necessary before these particular results can be interpreted with certainty. For the time being, however, we argue that the weight of evidence suggests deocclusivization of BP /ɲ/ is not the result of hypoarticulation.

The place of articulation of BP /ɲ/ is also of interest. It is far more posterior than anticipated, given reports for other Romance languages (Recasens et al., 1995) and our own findings in the related language PS. The nasalized approximant of BP is not identical, however, to the oral approximant /j/ in its place of articulation, demonstrating that it has a unique place of articulation intermediate between the canonical alveolo-palatal nasal of PS and the oral palatal approximant of BP. Thus, describing the phonetic realization of /ɲ/ as [j͂] may not be completely accurate.

sec.title: 6 Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: Our EPG data indicate that the consonant usually transcribed as [ɲ] in both PS and BP is articulated differently in the two languages.10 PS /ɲ/ generally presents a wide pattern of occlusion including the alveolar and front palatal area, consistent with its description as an alveolo-palatal nasal stop, as in Figure 11c (Fernández Planas, 2009; Martínez Celdrán & Fernández Planas, 2007). Only rarely do we find PS tokens that lack complete occlusion (Figure 11d). In BP, the majority of tokens show a pattern consistent with that of an approximant, that is, they manifest an open channel (Figure 11b). A minority of BP tokens, especially after /i/, may be described as nasal palatal stops (Figure 11a). The high frequency with which this BP segment is produced as an approximant could indicate that the approximant realization is an intended target, not a result of hypoarticulation. The results of our ‘hyperspeech’ experiment suggest that occlusivization is uncommon when the consonant appears in a focused word. Indeed, occlusivization is most common when the word is unfocused. The realization of both occluded and unoccluded palatal nasals in BP suggests a more posterior target than the palatal nasal of PS (and Catalan; Recasens & Espinosa, 2006). Though typically produced as a nasalized approximant, the BP palatal nasal still manifests more anterior linguopalatal contact than the oral approximant /j/.

caption.p: Examples of palatal nasal consonants in BP (a–b) and PS (c–d) at the point of maximum constriction. The words are vinha (a), canha (b), viña (c), and caña (d)

sec.p: All of this leads us to speculate on the intended articulatory targets of BP and PS palatal nasals, what is expected to occur when they undergo lenition, and whether our data cast any light on debates over palatal complexity (Keating, 1988; Keating & Lahiri, 1993; Lahiri & Evers, 1991; Recasens et al., 1995).

First, what is the articulatory target of palatal nasals in PS? If we take the most frequent articulation (at least in laboratory speech) as exemplary of the target articulation, then Figure 11c is the most likely representative. Here, the consonant is both alveopalatal and occluded. In a handful of cases, deocclusion occurs (Figure 11d). Deocclusion is presumably a result of articulatory undershoot; it resembles the situation described in Recasens et al. (1995) and Straka (1979) and has analogues in the voiced stop inventory of the language.

The matter of the articulatory target is not as straightforward in BP. The most frequent articulation in our BP corpus is the post-palatal, unoccluded token represented in Figure 11b. If this is the articulatory target intended by BP speakers, then the minority, occluded cases (Figure 11a) should in fact be regarded as examples of fortition. On the other hand, since the occluded tokens occur largely in the environment of /i/ it is possible that the post-palatal occluded nasal is the articulatory target but it is only reached when the tongue happens to be in an elevated position with significant contact along the lateral edges of the palate, as is typical for /i/ (Buchaillard, Perrier, & Payan, 2009).

One might wonder if the occluded PS token is the intended articulatory target for BP. This would suggest that not only has deocclusion occurred in BP, but the coronal gesture has been deleted, leaving behind a dorsally-articulated approximant. This would lend support to the palatal complexity argument of Keating (1988), among others, but crucially requires us to accept a configuration like Figure 11c as the articulatory target for palatal nasals in BP. This is problematic for a number of reasons. First of all, in our corpus we have very little evidence that a configuration like Figure 11c ever occurs among BP palatal nasals. Second, Portuguese once had a contrast between two different palatal nasals (a state of affairs unknown in the history of Spanish). The BP unoccluded palatal nasal may be a conservative trait since at some point in the history of Portuguese, a nasalized palatal approximant contrasted with a palatal nasal stop in different lexical items (Shosted & Hualde, 2010; Williams, 1962). The occluded and unoccluded tokens now vary considerably in BP (as our data show), but we find virtually no evidence of an anterior articulation. Finally, we note that in our ‘hyperspeech’ experiment, the palatal nasal is most frequently realized as an approximant in focused position; it is occluded only when unfocused. If we associate hyperarticulation with focus for the purposes of this experiment, at least, then we must conclude that the hyperarticulated realization of BP /ɲ/ is an approximant, not a stop. We find no compelling reason, therefore, to conclude that the articulatory target of the BP palatal nasal shares much in common with the articulatory target of the PS occluded alveopalatal nasal (Figure 11c). Thus, it is unclear how the BP data could lend support to the argument that palatals are articulated by means of independent coronal and dorsal gestures.

We note, however, that our data are not conclusive regarding the position of the tongue in regions where linguopalatal contact is not made. In other words, the tongue blade could be quite close to the hard palate in the anterior region of articulations like those represented in Figure 11a–b, even though no contact registers on the electropalate. Some other instrumental form of inquiry such as electromagnetic articulography, magnetic resonance imaging, or ultrasonography could be used to estimate the distance of the tongue from the hard palate and deal more conclusively with the problem of palatal complexity.

caption.p: Means and standard deviations for measures of anteriority (CAp), centrality (CCp), posteriority (CP), and consonantal length

ack.p: We wish to thank James Scobbie and two anonymous reviewers for their insightful commentary on this manuscript. Thanks also to Alan Wrench for his assistance with the EPG hardware. We are grateful to Dr. Mark Huls, D. M. D., P. C., and his staff for donating their time to cast the dental models; also to John Broughton and Bertha Bates at InciDental for the manufacture of the electropalates. We acknowledge support from the University of Illinois Research Board, Award # 10116. This manuscript has benefited from the insights of audience members at LSRL 2009 and from discussions with our colleagues at the University of Illinois. We thank our subjects for their patient participation in this study. Any omissions or errors are solely our responsibility.

fn.p: Borzone de Manrique (1980) and Quilis (1993) both argue that palatals are longer than other segments in Spanish.
An anonymous reviewer points out that the occluded realization of /ɲ/ is more frequent in the north and central-west regions of Brazil.

Some have argued that deocclusivization of both Portuguese /ɲ/ and /λ/ is unique to the former colonies of Portugal, due perhaps to the influence of various linguistic substrates (Leite de Vasconcelos, 1901; Silva Neto, 1986).
Nasal manner (i.e., the presence of nasality) can be detected with considerable success using acoustics alone (Pruthi & Espy-Wilson, 2004).

An anonymous reviewer points out that an alternative would be to examine the BP nasalized palatal approximant that occurs in forms like põe [po͂j͂] ‘put.3p.sg.’, cãibra [kɐ͂j͂mbɾɐ] ‘cramp’, and além [ale͂j͂] ‘beyond’. However, this sound (which is not represented in PS), does not occur intervocalically in BP (except as the realization of the palatal nasal, as we will show). Nor is its articulatory nature altogether clear, particularly in final position (Shosted, 2006, 2011b). For these reasons, we chose to compare the oral palatal approximants of the two languages.

In the context of reporting the results of Experiment II, this phrase will be referred to schematically as a ‘/nh/ × /nj/ phrase’ because /nh/ appears in first/focused position and /nj/ appears in second/unfocused position; other types include /nj/ × /nh/, /nh/ × /j/, and /j/ × /nh/, adhering to the same convention.

In fact, the resulting value may be greater than or equal to 6 in the case of the first/anterior-most pair of rows, since the left- and right-most sensors in the second row are unmatched by ‘corner’ sensors in the first row of a Reading-style artificial palate.

An alternative method measures “the connectivity between the right and left sides of the palate”, resulting in a continuous rather than binomial value (Articulate Instruments Ltd., 2008, pp. 33–34; McCann & Wrench, 2007).

When interpreting the palatograms in Figures 4 and 5, it is helpful to remember that dark shading across a row or multiple rows does not indicate complete occlusion for any particular token, since shading represents probabilistic activation of a sensor across repetitions of a token. A variety of configurations can result in occlusion across repetitions. These palatograms are best interpreted in relation to statistics on the frequency of complete occlusion, which were calculated on each token individually and are presented in Section 3.2.5. Occlusion frequency statistics should be taken as the definitive statement on occlusion for our data. The palatograms are presented to give a better sense of variable place of articulation and constriction across repetitions.

We remind the reader that our results pertain to only two varieties of BP, one spoken in southeastern Brazil (Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo; Speakers 1 and 2) and the other spoken in the northeast (Salvador, Bahia; Speaker 3). We lack sufficient data to make definitive statements about the articulation of the palatal nasal in either of these dialects individually. We therefore commend the topic for further instrumental study by researchers who have access to larger, more homogeneous populations from various regions of Brazil.
